Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund additional and back-up equipment on the R/V Marcus Langseth, a 235? Global seismic vessel with general oceanographic capabilities. The vessel is owned by NSF and operated by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University under a cooperative agreement. The Langseth is different than other vessels in the Academic Fleet in that it is a designated National Facility. It provides a unique combination of capabilities for imaging the oceans, the seafloor and the solid earth beneath the sea. It is the only vessel in the word dedicated to academic research that is capable of conducting 3D seismic surveys as well as extended offset 2D surveys. The tuned, linear source array, consisting of up to 36 air-guns, with a total capacity of 6,600 cu in is also unique asset of this vessel.

In 2014, R/V Langseth completed 139 days, 114 (82%) of which were NSF funded. In 2015, the schedule shows 228 days, 73% (167 days) of which are NSF funded. Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment requested in this proposal includes:

1) Automatic voltage regulators $49,071
2) Inmarsat C Felcom 18 $11,913
3) Simrad GC-80 $33,667
4) Power Synchronizing Module $44,175
5) Phased Bridge Modifications $91,440
6) Overhaul and upgrade of Dynacon Traction Winch $372,500
$602,766
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 SSSE award funded critical electrical and navigation component upgrades for equipment on the the R/V Marcus G. Langseth.  The R/V Langseth has two shaft generators that generate electrical power for the vessel in combination with ship's engines.  The failure of a original analog voltage regulators (20+ years old) on one of the shaft generators led to finding out that spare parts were no longer available for these units.  The original manufacturer, Leroy Somer, was able to supply upgraded automatic digital voltage regulators that removed a critical point of failure for operation of the vessel. The second component upgraded was a new Simrad GC-80 gyrocompass with digital repeaters.  This gyrocompass provides the navigation datastrings that supply the other ship's bridge equipment.  This equipment replaces the 30+ year old Sperry MK27 gyrocompass  that had been used on 3 vessels and required ongoing calibration and maintenance and an analog to digital converters to translate datastrings.  This equipment was no longer supported by Sperry so parts were not available.   Moving to a new, essentially maintenance free, Simrad gyro with digital outputs simplifies electronics, improves reliability, and removes another critical point of failure for the vessel operations of the Langseth. Both upgrades are important for success of  future science operations.
